channel.title: 经济学人
channel.description: 这是一个追踪经济学人news的种子

item.title: "我们载歌载舞，谈论着我们的新生活。"在经历了两年的战争和苦难之后，三位乌克兰学校的朋友得以在离校舞会上首次重聚。摄影师 @pollybraden 追踪了他们两年的旅程。
item.description:
“We were singing and dancing and talking about our new lives.”

After two years of war and hardship three Ukrainian school friends were able to reunite for the first time at a leavers’ prom. Photographer @pollybraden followed their journeys for two years https://t.co/7rUWIPKKUv

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: 据业内资深人士称，自 2014 年执政以来，纳伦德拉-莫迪（Narendra Modi）政府已关闭或耗尽了数千家慈善机构。
item.description:
Since coming to power in 2014, Narendra Modi’s administration has shut or depleted thousands of charities, according to industry veterans.

The details of the crackdown often appear more vindictive than based on genuine ideological difference https://t.co/r1Cg0WVVru 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: 以色列极端正统派教徒的征兵豁免正在产生政治后果。军警对宗教学生施压的想法可能会导致各政党抛弃总理，使其联盟垮台。
item.description:
A conscription exemption for ultra-Orthodox Israelis is having political consequences. The very idea of military police press-­ganging religious students could lead political parties to abandon the prime minister, bringing down his coalition https://t.co/Mu5M0VYsRX 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: 一些大学，尤其是大城市里的前技术学院和理工学院，已经变得异常多样化。好成绩、高期望值和不愿意出远门是👇......的原因。
item.description:
Some universities, especially former technical colleges and polytechnics in big cities, have grown exceptionally diverse. Good grades, high expectations and reluctance to travel explain why https://t.co/XJCm9UpzUk 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: 墨西哥总统正在与腐败指控作斗争。他否认有任何不法行为。但事实是，安德烈斯-曼努埃尔-洛佩斯-奥夫拉多尔在解决社会问题方面做得太少👇。
item.description:
Mexico’s president is fighting claims of corruption. He denies any wrongdoing.

But the truth is that Andrés Manuel López Obrador has done too little to tackle the problem in society https://t.co/KoMjUWi2Nx 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: 西方的敌人面临着从贸易禁运到金融制裁等一系列措施。然而，这些措施难以应对 "第三国 "日益增长的金融复杂性，这些国家既没有实施西方制裁，自身也没有面临制裁。
item.description:
Enemies of the West face a range of measures, from trade embargoes to financial sanctions.

Yet these struggle to contend with the growing financial sophistication of “third countries”, which neither impose Western sanctions nor face sanctions themselves https://t.co/CGFj7jP8Tz

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: 性问题被认为是造成五分之一到一半离婚的原因。减少这一数字将使许多成人和儿童免于痛苦和贫困👇。
item.description:
Sexual issues are thought to contribute to between a ﬁfth and half of all divorces. Reducing that number would spare many adults and children from misery and impoverishment https://t.co/gO5HNIid68 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: "艰难的大森林》既是一部寻宝游戏，也是一部关于流亡的感人冥想。小说的形式既是一次神奇的神秘之旅，也是一次骚乱的冒险和一个扭曲的童话👇。
item.description:
“Hard by a Great Forest” is at once a scavenger hunt and an affecting meditation on exile. The novel takes the form of a magical mystery tour, a riotous adventure and a warped fairy tale https://t.co/m7NwHvSzLY 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: 德国已经享受了八十年的和平，回避核武器，但仍为挑起两次世界大战而羞愧难当。德国国防部长发出的 "具备战争能力"--并尽快达到这一目标--的信息反映了时代的变迁
item.description:
Germany has enjoyed eight decades of peace, shuns nuclear weapons and still shudders with shame for instigating two world wars. Its defence minister’s message to get “war-capable”—and to get there fast—reflects the changing times https://t.co/0dXpnZfcIG pic.twitter.com/hywRUM2RQN

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: 高端时尚界又添新成员。我们将解释古驰、普拉达和蒂芙尼为何在零售地产上大举下注👇。
item.description:
High-end fashion has some new houses. We explain why Gucci, Prada and Tiffany’s are betting big on retail property https://t.co/8xKP0niddF 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: 硅谷新发现的清醒有很多值得庆祝的地方。初创企业不再不惜一切代价追求增长。创始人重新发现了节俭。假以时日，独角兽的时代可能不会被错过 🦄。
item.description:
There is plenty to celebrate in the newfound sobriety of Silicon Valley. Startups have stopped espousing growth at all costs. Founders have rediscovered frugality. Many are being cautious with hiring.

In time, the age of the unicorn may not be missed https://t.co/OHqsfGwhBk 🦄

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: 欧洲各国在处理乌克兰难民问题上稍微强硬一点，例如削减他们应得的福利，实际上会受到他们本国政府的欢迎。为什么？
item.description:
A little steeliness in how European countries deal with Ukrainian refugees—for example a cut in beneﬁts they are entitled to—would actually be welcomed by their home govern­ment. Why? https://t.co/graycRQZms 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: 刚果东部地区几十年来一直受到邻国的干涉和争夺，很少有地方像刚果东部这样长期遭受苦难。另一场灾难性战争是可以避免的，但需要外部压力👇。
item.description:
Few places have suffered such prolonged misery as eastern Congo, a region that has been meddled in and fought over by its neighbours for decades.

Another catastrophic war can be prevented, but it requires outside pressure https://t.co/pSGrCWP5YV 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: 重塑中国龙的形象会让中国看起来更友好吗？北京官员似乎希望如此👇。
item.description:
Will rebranding the Chinese dragon make the country look more friendly? Beijing officials seem to hope so https://t.co/SaZ5XxWoIq 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: "凯文-卡萨斯-萨莫拉（Kevin Casas-Zamora）说："我们生活在一个极度不确定的时代。"这位政治学家在一篇特约文章中警告说："年轻一代对民主能否回应他们的关切失去信心，这并非巧合。
item.description:
“We live in a time of radical uncertainty,” says Kevin Casas-Zamora.

“It is not coincidental that younger generations are losing faith in democracy’s ability to respond to their concerns,” the political scientist warns in a guest essay https://t.co/pxP4nmnPhD

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: "北约是美国联盟的黄金标准"我们的副主编在 "制衡 "播客中说，如果美国退出北约，可能会破坏与其他国家的协议👇。
item.description:
“NATO is the gold standard of American alliances.”

Our deputy editor says that if the US stepped back from NATO it could damage agreements with other countries, on our “Checks and Balance” podcast https://t.co/pE7dLums6l 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: 我们的记者挑选了五本预示着当今重大事件的书籍。这些书都是十多年前出版的，它们提供了预示和教训👇。
item.description:
Our journalists have picked five books that foreshadow the big stories of the present. All published more than a decade ago, they offer portents and lessons https://t.co/WsXgQQORis 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: 一项新的研究表明，即使能够达成停火协议，加沙地带的卫生系统也会遭受巨大破坏，以至于会有更多的人死亡👇。
item.description:
Many doctors who have worked in other war zones say that conditions in Gaza are the worst they have seen.

Even if a ceasefire can be agreed, the damage to the strip’s health system is so great that many more deaths will follow, a new study suggests https://t.co/Fp41XB5DEi 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: 日本人对散户投资的反感可以追溯到 20 世纪 90 年代初，当时股市泡沫破裂。随着日经 225 指数屡创新高，他们正如愿以偿👇。
item.description:
An aversion among Japanese to retail investing dates back to the early 1990s, when a stockmarket bubble burst.

Officials have long desired a shift in attitudes. As the Nikkei 225 hits record highs, they are getting their wish https://t.co/9iU2VFEJUp 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: 鲍里斯-皮斯托瑞斯希望德国成为欧洲防务的 "中流砥柱"。但德国国防部长面临着艰巨的任务👇。
item.description:
Boris Pistorius wants to make Germany the “backbone” of European defence. But huge tasks lie ahead for the country’s defence minister https://t.co/c3sOdlJgPN 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: 美国 11 月的总统选举几乎肯定会是近 70 年来首次重选。通过我们的选举民调跟踪器，您可以找到最新的民调、两位主要候选人的简短介绍以及选举日程中的关键日期： 👇
item.description:
America’s presidential election in November will almost certainly be the first rematch in almost 70 years. Find the latest polls, short guides to the two main candidates and key dates in the electoral calendar with our election poll tracker: https://t.co/ir7efopIJY 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: 美国大学正遭受一场合法性危机，这让它们的校长们备受关注 👇
item.description:
America’s universities are suffering from a crisis of legitimacy that has put their presidents under a microscope https://t.co/eCNr62bDdN 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: 唐纳德-特朗普的审判会如何左右选民？ ⬇️
item.description:
How might Donald Trump’s trials sway voters? https://t.co/2vvsDFjUZj ⬇️

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: 欧洲国家在处理乌克兰难民问题上稍微强硬一点，例如削减他们应得的福利，实际上会受到他们本国政府的欢迎。为什么？
item.description:
A little steeliness in how European countries deal with Ukrainian refugees—for example a cut in beneﬁts they are entitled to—would actually be welcomed by their home govern­ment. Why? https://t.co/VJVzDtgSFm pic.twitter.com/5tEGTkiJix

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: 土耳其是世界第三大电视出口国。是什么让土耳其的电视节目如此值得狂欢？它们拥有迷人的风景、奢华的服装和英俊的演员👇。
item.description:
Turkey is the third-largest exporter of TV. What makes its shows so binge­-worthy? They boast glamorous landscapes, luxuri­ous costumes and handsome actors https://t.co/5MtVewofC0 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: 布朗比马是一种浪漫的动物。澳大利亚的野马是早期移民的骏马的后代，它们在澳大利亚大陆最高的山脉--澳大利亚阿尔卑斯山上漫步。但是，一场大规模的捕杀行动正在进行👇。
item.description:
Brumbies are romantic creatures. Australia’s wild horses, descended from the steeds of early settlers, roam the continent’s highest ranges, the Australian Alps. But a big cull is under way https://t.co/un6HCdUcjK 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: 自 2021 年海地总统遇害以来，海地变得越来越难以治理。现在，案件出现了意想不到的转折 ⬇️
item.description:
Haiti has become ever more ungovernable since the murder of its president in 2021. Now the case has taken an unexpected turn https://t.co/EZSLFvqpfa ⬇️

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: 关于长尾蚴的研究仍在进行中。但它与其他感染后病症的相似之处可能会揭示其病因--以及如何治疗 👇。
item.description:
Research on long covid is still a work in progress. But its similarities with other post-infectious conditions could shine a light on what causes it—and how it could be treated https://t.co/e3R9Uwh88K 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: 基尔-斯塔默爵士的传记揭示了这位改革者对政治的不适应。该传记认为，工党政府将为英国带来三种文化转变 👇。
item.description:
A biography of Sir Keir Starmer reveals a reformer ill at ease in politics. It suggests a Labour government would bring three cultural shifts to Britain https://t.co/YzkV3nyoM7 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024

item.title: EssilorLuxottica 是世界上最大的眼镜制造商。现在，该品牌希望朝着以技术为基础的新方向发展。这是它的两大雄心壮志： 👇
item.description:
EssilorLuxottica is the the world’s biggest maker of spectacles. Now the brand wants to go in a new, tech-based direction. These are its two big ambitions: https://t.co/WK59B36RVH 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 24, 2024
